abstract.para: This data set includes vegetation classifications from the Willamette National Forest (years 1993, 1996, 1997, 2002, and 2008) and from 1988 thematic mapper satellite image.

intellectualRights.para: Any Andrews Experimental Forest data set and accompanying metadata available on these web pages can be downloaded for academic, research, recreational, and other professional purposes. Permission to download data sets is granted to the Data User without a fee subject to the following terms. The Data User will:

listitem.para: notify the designated contact (e.g., Principle Investigator or Data Set Contact) when any derivative work based on or derived from the data and documentation is distributed;
notify users that such derivative work is a modified version and not the original data and documentation distributed by the Andrews LTER;
not redistribute original data and documentation;

acknowledge the support of the Andrews LTER and appropriate NSF Grant numbers in any publications using these data and documentation. (See general acknowledgement below and see web page for specific data citation for each study data set);

send two reprints of any publications resulting from use of the data and documentation to the following address: Andrews Experimental Forest LTER Program, c/o Don Henshaw, Forestry Sciences Lab, 3200 SW Jefferson Way, Corvallis, OR 97331

intellectualRights.para: By using or copying these data and documentation, the Data User agrees to abide by the terms of this agreement. The Andrews Experimental Forest LTER Site shall have the right to terminate this agreement immediately by written notice upon the Data User's breach of, or non-compliance with, any of its terms. The Data User may be held responsible for any misuse that is caused or encouraged by the Data User's failure to abide by the terms of this agreement. Thank you for your cooperation. We hope your collaboration with our site is a productive one!

Disclaimer: While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "as is". The Andrews Experimental Forest LTER shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of data sets.

General acknowledgement: Data were provided by the HJ Andrews Experimental Forest research program, funded by the National Science Foundation's Long-Term Ecological Research Program (DEB 08-23380), US Forest Service Pacific Northwest Research Station, and Oregon State University.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Andrews Experimental Forest within the Willamette National Forest, western Cascades, Oregon, USA.

purpose.para: To document the distribution of vegetation over the Andrews Experimental Forest and changes over time.

section.para: An update history is logged and maintained with each new version of every dataset.

fixed database linkage errors and will re-run into PASTA
fixed dataset eml errors to re-run into PASTA

description.para: Processing Procedures - TV061

TV06101:Willamette National Forest vegetation classification (1997), with 2008 updated harvest units, using aerial photography and satellite imagery. Created by WNF using aerial photography and satellite imagery. Clipped to the Andrews boundary, Coverage was converted to a shapefile and projected to Nad83 Datum. Harvest units and meadows were updated with information from 2008 Andrews LiDAR data.
Processing Procedures - TV061 (1)

TV06102: Willamette National Forest vegetation classification (1996) clipped to the Andrews Experimental Forest. Created by WNF using aerial photography and satellite imagery. Created by WNF using aerial photography and satellite imagery. George Lienkaemper imported, clipped, and did some edits in 1997 Coverage was converted to a shapefile and projected to Nad83 Datum
Processing Procedures - TV061 (2)

TV06103: Willamette National Forest vegetation classification (1993) clipped to the Andrews Experimental Forest. Created by WNF using aerial photography and satellite imagery. Created by WNF using aerial photography and satellite imagery. George Lienkaemper imported, clipped, and did some edits in 1997 Coverage was converted to a shapefile and projected to Nad83 Datum
Processing Procedures - TV061 (3)

TV06104: Willamette National Forest vegetation classification (2002) clipped to the Andrews Experimental Forest. Created by WNF using aerial photography and satellite imagery. Created by WNF using aerial photography and satellite imagery.

The VEG table exists in both Oracle and INFO databases. It was originally developed from queries of the district VEGIS database (oracle) and then transferred to INFO and attached to the VEG layer in GIS. Most attention was given to populating the following fields: yr_origin, size_class, land_use, land_cover, and activity. No attempt was made to ensure that all other fields were populated. This forestwide coverage was compiled from district data July, 2000. Forestwide coverages are compiled from district information as needed, on average every 6 months. The currency of data for individual polygons varies across the forest depending on district update and edit cycles. Coverage was converted to a shapefile and projected to Nad83 Datum
Processing Procedures - TV061 (4)
TV06105:Stand age classification of 1988 thematic mapper satellite image, Andrews Experimental Forest. classified satellite imaged, classified by Warren Cohen and Maria Fiorella at CFSL

project.title: Long-Term Ecological Research

address.deliveryPoint: Oregon State University;Dept. of Forest Science;321 Richardson Hall
US Forest Service ;Pacific NW Research Station ;3200 SW Jefferson Way
Oregon State University;Department of Geosciences; Wilkinson Hall 104
USDA Forest Service;Pacific NW Research Station;3200 SW Jefferson Way
H.J. Andrews Experimental Forest; PO Box 300

abstract.para: The H.J. Andrews Experimental Forest is a living laboratory that provides unparalleled opportunities for the study of forest and stream ecosystems in the central Cascade Range of Oregon. Since 1980, as a part of the National Science Foundation Long Term Ecological Research (NSF-LTER) program, the Andrews Experimental Forest has become a leader in the analysis of forest and stream ecosystem dynamics.

Long-term field experiments and measurement programs have focused on climate dynamics, streamflow, water quality, and vegetation succession. Currently researchers are working to develop concepts and tools needed to predict effects of natural disturbance, land use, and climate change on ecosystem structure, function, and species composition.

The Andrews Experimental Forest is administered cooperatively by the USDA Forest Service Pacific Northwest Research Station, Oregon State University and the Willamette National Forest. Funding for the research program comes from the National Science Foundation (NSF), US Forest Service Pacific Northwest Research Station, Oregon State University, and other sources.

project.funding: Data were provided by the HJ Andrews Experimental Forest research program, funded by the National Science Foundation's Long-Term Ecological Research Program (DEB 08-23380), US Forest Service Pacific Northwest Research Station, and Oregon State University. National Science Foundation: DEB0823380

descriptor.name: Long-Term Ecological Research
descriptor.descriptorValue: The Andrews Forest is situated in the western Cascade Range of Oregon, and covers the entire 15,800-acre (6400-ha) drainage basin of Lookout Creek. Elevation ranges from 1350 to 5340 feet (410 to 1630 m). Broadly representative of the rugged mountainous landscape of the Pacific Northwest, the Andrews Forest contains excellent examples of the region's conifer forests and associated wildlife and stream ecosystems. These forests are among the tallest and most productive in the world, with tree heights of often greater than 250 ft (75 m). Streams are steep, cold and clean, providing habitat for numerous aquatic organisms.

spatialVector.entityDescription: Vegetation map of the HJ Andrews, created by the Willamette National Forest using aerial photography, satellite imagery, and LiDAR. The data was compiled in 1997 and updated with 2008 LiDAR imagery.

description.para: Created by WNF using aerial photography and satellite imagery.
coverage was converted to a shapefile and projected from NAD27 to NAD83

Data was converted into a file geodatabase, and edited with boundaries derived from the 2008 LiDAR flight information. Harald Zald created the harvest layer, and Theresa Valentine inserted and corrected topology errors using topological tools in ArcGIS 10.1
Data was converted back to a shapefile for distribution.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Year of Origin for both natural and managed stands. The year of origin may indicate when a managed stand was certified as reforested. It does not take into account the age of seedlings if planted. Some units may have needed up to10 years to be certified. A value of 0 may indicate no-data.

textDomain.definition: Sequential unique whole numbers that represent years.

attribute.attributeDefinition: predominant size class of trees MOMS - Mature and OverMature Survey (Willamette Natl Forest 1/91) was a stand condition mapping and old growth inventory project accomplished primarily by means of aerial photo-interpretation. Size class 5 from MOMS was redefined into size classes 5.1 and 6.1 using regression equations of crown diameter to predict size class. NOTE: THESE ARE VERY APPROXIMATE

attribute.attributeDefinition: These codes are not documented and appear to have some errors, including null values for areas within the Andrews. Some of the values were identified by the Willamette National Forest GIS specialist.

codeDefinition.definition: Barrenland: Land on which disturbance frequency, ground surface characteristics, or potential site capability inhibits the establishment of a closed canopy forest. Examples are lava flows, mud flows, glacial outwash, periodically inundated flood plains, landform failures such as slumps, avalanches, talus slopes, rock, cinders.

Aquatic: Land on which grasses, grass-like plants or forbs are structurally supported by water year-round or seasonally and may be either rooted or not rooted in substrate. Land in which the herbaceous lifeform layer qualifies as aquatic but which supports either a tree or shrub layer having a canopy cover of 10% or greater will be classified under treeland, shrubland or dwarf shrubland.

Open water: Land which is covered by water year-round and which may support free-floating vegetation (full support by water and not rooted in substrate), if vegetation is present at all. Permanently flooded lands lying below the deep-water boundary of wetlands, where water is the medium within which the dominant organisms live, i.e. deep-water habitats. Examples: Ponds, lakes, rivers, streams, estuaries, reservoirs below draw-down area.

Herbland: Land on which grasses, grass-like plants or forbs dominate the vegetation. The shrub and/or tree layer, if present, is less than 10% canopy cover for each lifeform layer. Includes meadows (wet and dry), bogs, fens, etc.
could be hardwood or managed stands

attribute.attributeDefinition: percent of covered ground area covered by the vertical projection of live foliage of all trees in all canopy layers in a stand. Small openings are included; overlapping foliage is counted only once; canopy cover cannot exceed 100%

codeDefinition.definition: all values are 0, so assuming not calculated for this area

description.para: The VEG table exists in both Oracle and INFO databases. It was originally developed from queries of the district VEGIS database (oracle) and then transferred to INFO and attached to the VEG layer in GIS. Most attention was given to populating the following fields: yr_origin, size_class, land_use, land_cover, and activity. No attempt was made to ensure that all other fields were populated. This forestwide coverage was compiled from district data July, 2000. Forestwide coverages are compiled from district information as needed, on average every 6 months. The currency of data for individual polygons varies across the forest depending on district update and edit cycles.
data was converted to a shapefile and projected to NAD83.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Stand. Seven digit index number for the polygon
Year of origin for both natural and managed stands.

textDomain.definition: whole number representing year

attribute.attributeDefinition: Size classification. Size class of layer 1 (r6 size class codes). The predominant size class of all trees in a given layer of a stand based on diameter at breast height, with a minimum height of 6" for size class 1. Note: size class information is sparse for managed stands. This information is best for natural stands.

codeDefinition.definition: No data. Includes nonforest, private, stands without trees, natural stands with no size class data and most managed stands.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Species 1 (major species). Most abundant tree species in primary canopy layer in a managed or natural stand (pnw6 char plant code) within National Forest land.
Species 2 (minor species). Second most abundant tree species in secondary canopy layer in a manged or natural stand (pnw6 char plant code) on National Forest land.
Number of layers. Estimated number of canopy layers in the stand for forested stands.
Last overstory cut. Activity code for the most recent overstory cut.
Last overstory year. Year of the last clearcut or overstory removal.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Commercial thin year. Year of the last commercial thinning activity record.

textDomain.definition: whole number representing year

attribute.attributeDefinition: Timber type. Timber types are classifications of stand species composition from the original timber inventory used in the development of the Forest Plan. These classifications, in association with timber size, are used to identify the correct yield table for ASQ and PSQ calculations. (INTERIM FIELD).

Condition class (INTERIM FIELD). Classification based on size class for natural stands & managed stands with non-regenerative harvest (partial) cuts for clearcuts, overstory removals & partial cuts with evidence of regeneration.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Land cover. Land cover classification divides the land surface into categories based upon feature of the earth surface (vegetation, rock, ice/snow,water, etc.)

codeDefinition.definition: Agricultural: Cultivated land, permanent pasture, orchards, seedorchards

Dwarf-shrubland: Land on which the shrubs dominate the vege-tation and their cover is greater than 10%. Shrubs are generally less than 20 inches (.5 meters) in height. Trees, if present, have a canopy cover of less than 10%.

Forestland: Land in which the tree layer is represented by individuals generally over 16 feet (5 meters) tall that are woody perennials and usually single-stemmed. The trees form a canopy cover of 10% or greater. (NOTE: When stands classified as FL are harvested, they will NOT be recoded to another land cover code such as DX or SX even though the vegetation height is altered. We can identify these stands through other fields.)
Forbland: Land on which 50% or greater of the vegetationcanopy cover is composed of broad-leaved herbaceous plant other than grass or grass-like plants.
Grassland: Land on which 50% or greater of the vegetation canopy cover is composed of species of the Gramineae, Cyperaceae or Juncaceae families (grasses, sedges, and reeds).

Barrenland: Land on which disturbance frequency, ground surface characteristics, or potential site capability inhibits the establishment of a closed canopy forest. Examples are lava flows, mud flows, glacial outwash, periodically unindatedfloodplains, landform failures such as slumps, avalanches,talus slopes, rock, cinders.

Aquatic: Land on which grasses, grass-like plants or forbsare structually supported by water year round or seasonally and may be either rooted or not rooted in substate. Land in which the herbaceous lifeform layer qualifies as aquatic but which supports either a tree or shrub layer having a canopy cover of 10% or greater will be classified under treeland, shrubland, or dwarf-shrubland.
Snowfield/glacier: Land covered by permanent snowfield or glacier.

Shrubland: Land on which the shrubs dominate the vegetation and their cover is greater than 10%. Shrubs are 20 inches to 16 feet (.5 to 5 meters) tall and have a non-arborescent form. Trees, if present, have a canopy cover of less than 10%.

Open water: Land which is covered by water year round and which may support free-floating vegetation (full support by water and not rooted in substrate), if vegetation is present at all. Permanently flooded lands lying below the deepwater boundary of wetlands, where water is the medium within which the dominant organisms live, i.e. deep water habitats. Examples: Ponds, lakes, rivers, streams, estuaries, reservoirs below draw-down area.

Herbland: Land on which grasses, grass-like plants or forbs dominate the vegetation. The shrub and/or tree layer, if present is less than 10% canopy cover for each lifeform layer. Includes meadows (wet and dry), bogs, fens, etc.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Land use. Land use classification divides the land surface into categories based on the way the land is used (green tree retention, special habitats, buildings, etc.) This is a multiple field.

codeDefinition.definition: Agricultural land, cultivated land, pasture, orchard. (includes ecoclass codes AC,AG,AO)
Buildings, structures, roads (includes administrative sites, ecoclass codes AB, AX)
Dump for trash, garbage, etc.(ecoclass AD)
Rock and gravel storage area (ecoclass ABA1)

Managed stand. Stands that have had significant human intervention which alters the growth or structrure of the natural stand. *NOTE: There is a query to populate this from activity records. The information can then be verified by specialists as needed.
Natural stand. Stands that have had no harvest activities or that have not been changed significantly by human activities.
Water: Lakes (interim code -- only used on Middle Fork RD

attribute.attributeDefinition: Habitat features. Habitats with distinct features that occur in stand which my be important when considering management practices.

codeDefinition.definition: Recreation sites which change ecology, such as parks, playgrounds, etc.
Harvest unit containing GTRs -- all clumped
Harvest unit containing GTRs -- scattered and clumped
Road failure - area adjacent to road that is non-vegetated due to loss of soil from the construction of the road (eg, road cut failure, road fill failure, road drainage failure).

Dry Rock Garden-generally found on southern slopes on exposed rocky ridges or rock walls with patchy soil development; plant species are adapted to dry soil conditions. (Related plant associations: ROCK GARDEN (flat,xeric), ROCK GARDEN (steep, xeric))

Moist Rock Garden-characterized by steep slopes and wet seepy conditions through mid-July. Plant species are mixed hydric/xeric, depending on the water course. A canopy usually shades a large percentage of the area. (Related plant associations: ROCK GARDEN (steep,moist))
Hardwood inclusion-a patch of hardwood trees in a conifer stand that is too small or too irregularly shaped to map as a distinct stand.

Bog-Permanently wet, spongy ground dominated by Sphagnum and other acid-tolerant plants. Other common species include tofieldia (Tofieldia glandulosa), sedge (Carex sp.), bog blueberry (Vaccinium occidentale),spirea (Spirea douglasii), bog orchid (Habenaria sp.), sundews (Drosera sp.) and kalmia (Kalmia microphylla)

Dry Meadow-a meadow that is generally on south to southwest facing slopes and plants bloom early in the season when water is available. (Related plant associations: XETE-FERU, ELGL-BROMU, VISA-ERPE-ELGL, ERLA-PHHE, RUPA-POPH)
Mesic meadow-a meadow that is generally found on lower slopes or benches at middle elevations and which receives water into mid-summer. (Related plant associations: VACCI-SPDE/GRASS, VERAT-HELA).

Swamp-permanently wet area, often shaded by a canopy. Species which commonly inhabit swamps include Skunk cabbage (Lysichium americanum), Vine maple (Acer circinatum), Alder (Alnus sinuata), Devil''s club (Oplopanax horrium), Water hemlock (Cicuta douglasii), Speedwell (Veronica americana).

Sedge meadow - plant community dominated by sedges and to a lesser extent other graminoids, with a moderate to deep peaty soil and standing water during at least part of the growing season. (Related plant associations: SPDO-VAUL/CAREX, CAREX-SCMI, CAREX-CABI, SPIRA-SALIX/CAREX)

Wet Meadow - An area periodically saturated with the water tableat, near, or above the soil surface. Wetland obligative andfaculative species dominate. (Related plant associations: CAREX-CABI, CAREX-SCMI)
Sand blowout - Area of constantly shifting, very lightly vegetated, pumice and volcanic sand; usually found along the crest of the Cascades and near the base of post-Pleistocene cinder cones.
Pumice field - Area composed wholly of pumice which is just beginning to be colonized by plants.
Cone rim - Volcanic cone rim composed of pumice and volcanic sand (related plant associations: rock garden, flat xeric; ARNE-JUCO)
Cliff-steep vertical or overhanging rock face.
Gravel bar - feature associated with riparian areas which are a result of past flood events. (Not talus).
Landslide - soil movement caused by gravity, avalanche or fluvial activity.(Not talus).
Rock Outcrop-a rock pile or a monolith rock, emerging from the surrounding canopy. The rock is dry and bare, with the possible exception or moss or lichens.
Talus-the accumulation of broken rocks at the base of cliffs or other steep slopes. (Related plant association: TALUS)

Sitka Alder (rocky soil)-area dominated by Sitka alder (Alnus sinuata) and salmonberry (Rubus spectabilis) and characterized by steep rocky headwalls at elevations above 3900 feet. (Related plant associations: ALSI (rocky soil)).
Shrub lava-shrub field growing on a lava bed. (Related plant association: SHRUB (lava))

Vine Maple (rocky soil)-area dominated by vine maple and has a seasonal water supply which dries up by early summer. There is a small (1-2 inch) organic layer in the soil. (Related plant association: VINE MAPLE (rocky soil))

Vine Maple (talus)-a wet shrub field abundant with vine maple where water is near the surface and during portions of the year water flows through the subsurface rocks or comes to the surface in springs and seeps. (Related plant association: VINE MAPLE (talus)).
GTR stand -- clumps < .05 acres and/or individual scattered trees
Cave-natural underground chamber, cavern or cavelike overhang that is open to the surface.

Rare Forested Plant Association - a forested plant association that occurs at only 5 or fewer per district (uncommon= 6 to 11 sites per district). A preliminary status table is included in the FW-211 Implementation Guide and descriptions of all plant associations are in the WNF Plant Association Guide. Further data is needed to improve status table accuracy.
Mineral Deposits-includes elk salt licks and pigeon mineral springs.
Small openings- Gaps in the forest canopy, generally less than 1 acre in size that support a different biological community than the surrounding forest.
Snag Patches- Areas containing a high density of hard and/or soft snags. These may be either naturally formed or created
Water inlet for domestic use (*This code will be moved to land use in next vegis update)
Headwater- The place where a stream originates.
Pond- Small ephemeral or permanent body of water too small to bemapped on the water layer.
Spring- A surface discharge of water small enough to flow in a rivulet.
Seep- Place where a small spring emerges from the ground, generally forming a shallow pool, often a source for a creek.
Small Stream- Stream courses too small to be included on the stream layer

attribute.attributeDefinition: Cover percent of trees. The percent of ground area covered by the vertical projection of live foliage of all trees in all tree layers in a stand. Small openings in the canopy are included. Overlapping foliage is counted only once. Canopy cover cannot exceed 100%. See vegis data dictionary for examples.

textDomain.definition: whole numbers to 3 digits

attribute.attributeDefinition: Plant association. The potential natural plant community, defined as discrete, recurring collections of plant species which maintain stable populations over a long period of time. In some cases only a general classification of plant association is known for a polygon. These polygons are coded with a 2 character code and general description. Codes beginning with "A" will be migrated to "land_use." Codes ending in C0 (zero) were sometimes coded as CO in the database. This error will be corrected, but queries for that information need to include CO and C0.

codeDefinition.definition: Recreation areas, parks, play areas, golf courses
Subalpine fir, Mt. hemlock, Whitebark pine open parks with special conifers
Mt. Hemlock/dwarf huckleberry, rolling pumice, willam. SAF2
Grasslands, subalpine to alpine with scattered conifers
Dry meadow (water table available part of growing season)
Moist meadow (water table available all growing season)
Moist meadow with some scattered conifers
Subalpine/ alpine moist to wet meadows
Subalpine to alpine meadows with some scattered conifers
Tule meadow (standing water most or all of growing season)
Wet meadow (surface moist or wet all growing season)
Cinders, lava flow, mud flow, glacial wash (less than 10% vegetated)
Cinders, lavas, outwash with scattered conifers
Flood plain periodically denuded of vegetationx
Mine tailings, dredgings,human caused minimal vegetation potential
Rocky land with minimal vegetation potential
Talus land with minimal vegetation potential
Moist (mesic) shrubland, forest zone shrubs and shrubland
Moist (mesic) shrubland in forest zone with scattered conifers
Shrub wetlands, shrubs less then 16 ft. tal
Wet shrubland, shrub meadows with some scattered conifers
Running water - stream, river, creek, ditch

attribute.attributeDefinition: Land ownership on Willamette National Forest within the proclamation boundary.

parameter.description: a multiplier for reducing a distance obtained from a map by computation or scaling to the actual distance along the central meridian.
parameter.name: Scale factor at central meridian

parameter.description: The line of logitude at the center of the map projection
parameter.name: Longitude at central meridian

parameter.description: The latitude chosen as center of the projection
parameter.name: Latitude of projection origin

parameter.description: A value added in a rectangular coordinate system, usually used to avoid negative values
parameter.name: False Easting

parameter.description: A value added in a rectangular coordinate system, usually used to avoid negative values
parameter.name: False Northing

spatialRaster.entityDescription: Stand age classification of 1988 thematic mapper satellite image.

description.para: classified satellite imaged, classified by Warren Cohen and Maria Fiorella at CFSL
projected from NAD27 to NAD83

attribute.attributeDefinition: Internal feature number.

textDomain.definition: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Internal feature number.

textDomain.definition: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attribute.attributeDefinition: stand age classifcation
number of pixals with value attribute

textDomain.definition: whole number generated by computer
